Attribute: collection_date : 1996; geo_loc_name : Japan: Sakai City, Osaka prefecture; lat_lon : Missing; isolation_source : Human intestinal microflora; host : Homo sapiens; host_disease : Hemorrhagic colitis, HUS; collected_by : M Yoh, T Honda; host_tissue_sampled : Human feces; host_description : typical patient during the Sakai outbreak; culture_collection : ATCC:BAA-460; serotype : E. coli O157:H7; pathotype : EHEC, STEC; Sequencing Center : RIKEN; GOLD : Gc00046; Genbank : BA000007; Refseq : NC_002695; strain : SAKAI (EHEC)
Organism.Name: Escherichia coli O157:H7 str. Sakai
Description.Comment: Full genome sequenced type strain Escherichia coli O157:H7 str. SAKAI.  This strain is associated with Hamburger disease, which is caused by the contamination of meat products by enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC). The identifier O157:H7 refers to the serotype of EHEC, and reflects the specific antigenic markers found on the surface of the cell. EHEC attaches and effaces to cells in the large intestine.There are numerous differences that distinguish O157:H7 from K-12, hundreds of them associated with genomic islands in either strain, including at least 9 large PAIs in O157:H7 that encode virulence factors. A type III secretion system, the locus of enterocyte effacement, numerous toxins and adhesins, as well as fimbrial gene clusters and iron uptake systems are found in these PAIs. Pathogenicity genes are also found on the plasmid pO157. Escherichia coli O157:H7 strain Sakai. This strain of O157:H7 was isolated in a 1996 outbreak in Sakai, Japan.
Description.Organism.Name: Escherichia coli O157:H7 str. Sakai
Description.Title: Bacterial, clinical or host-associated sample for Escherichia coli O157:H7 str. SAKAI (EHEC)
Owner.Name: ATCC

Attribute: strain : RM8385; collected_by : USDA ARS PSM; collection_date : 2009-01; geo_loc_name : USA: Salinas, California; host : Bos taurus; host_disease : n/a; isolation_source : feces; lat_lon : 36.68 N 121.67 W; pathotype : STEC; serotype : O103
Organism.Name: Escherichia coli O103 str. RM8385
Description.Comment: The rise in foodborne-related outbreaks of non O157 shiga-toxin producing E. coli (STECs) emphasizes the importance of developing improved methods to rapidly detect and characterize STECs. The major serovars of STEC associated with illness have been O26, O111, O103, O121, O43, and O145, accounting for 25-50% of human illness caused by STECs and, in some cases, severe illness comparable to illness caused by E. coli O157:H7. Sequencing of STECs from the agriculturally important region of the California central coast will address the diversity of genomic content and physiology of STECs compared to E. coli O157.
Description.Organism.Name: Escherichia coli O103 str. RM8385
Description.Title: Pathogen: Bos taurus-associated sample of Escherichia coli O103
Owner.Name: United States Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service
